data.text: Are There Any Electric Bikes Suitable for Touring?

Does anyone know if there are any electric bikes, suitable for touring, which are being sold with a triple 22 32 44 at the front, and an 11-32 at the rear. I want to be able to ride my fully loaded bike up a 10 percent hill even with the battery flat. Occasionally I find myself camping miles from any electricity and cannot recharge for 2 or 3 days. I am in New Zealand. And I am retired so limit myself to around 50 kms (30 miles ) a day.
Check out the Cannondale Quick ebike

data.text: I am not sure if a company makes a Touring e-bike like say Trek and the 520!..I tour with my e-bike. Its a Bosch active line mid drive...its a commuter bike. Its a German Pegasus E-8 bikes. I carry two batteries. I get around 60-65 miles per battery...My daily average is around 60 miles. I also pull a trailer with it. I only use this set up for riding on roads..and stay at B&B's / Hotels for the most part. .I use the standard Trek 520 or my Cannondale X-7 for trails.
data.author: Martin Fano

data.text:
There is a retrofit kit from the UK called Revos which operates via a motor on the seat tube with an integrated roller that sits against the tyre. Cheap, effective but a bit crude as it is speed sensing not torque sensing. It leaves your existing groupset unaffected. https://revolutionworks.com/products/revos-with-200wh-battery
Revos eBike Kit With 200Wh Battery
revolutionworks.com
data.author: Simon Edmonds

data.text: Look at Tongsheng TSDZ2 mid drive motor. You could convert your existing tourer to electric with this. I have just built myself a steel tourer from scratch with a Microsoft Advent X drivetrain. With a 34t front crank it just eats hills and still rides nice with the motor off. No motor drag with the motor off. Mine is a 48 volt system, suggest a 36 volt may be better for touring, battery life may be better.
data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: I doubt you will find a 22/32/44 with an 11/32 Good luck.

data.text: Borrow an E-bike for just a few minutes, turn off the power, & try pedaling that thing. I think once you discover how heavy they are, you'll have more insight.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: I have a Raleigh Motus GT city/tourer which runs a Bosch Active Line Plus mid drive motor. It has a 500w battery above the motor but you can add a second pannier rack battery too and double the motor capacity. The Bosch system is very flexible and a twin battery set up is easily configured. I ride it pretty much in Eco 90% of the time. On the flatter roads and paths the motor isnâ€™t even engaged above 15.5mph so I get decent mileage upwards of 70 miles on a full single 500w battery.
